column1: According to the course introduction, what is the simplest definition of computer science?
column2: It is the science of computers.

column1: What is the fundamental purpose of science, as described in the course?
column2: Science is about understanding things.

column1: The course draws an analogy between biology understanding living things and computer science understanding _____.
column2: computers

column1: What common devices, besides laptops, are described as being 'in essence computers'?
column2: Phones and tablets.

column1: What is the focus of this computer science course, as opposed to being a 'how-to manual'?
column2: It introduces the ideas that computer scientists use to think about and understand computers.

column1: What is the primary method of learning promoted by the course, based on the science of the brain?
column2: Active learning through practice, as we do not learn well passively.

column1: What are the two main forms of practice for learning knowledge mentioned in the course?
column2: Testing yourself and doing quizzes.

column1: Besides videos, what other learning resource is described as a 'core part' of the course?
column2: The textbook with its readings.

column1: What are the main activities for practising the application of knowledge in this course?
column2: Discussions and peer review exercises.

column1: What is the key skill you learn by giving feedback in peer review exercises?
column2: You learn how to evaluate your own work and the work of others.

column1: In the course's peer review activities, what mark scheme do students use to assess each other's work?
column2: The exact same mark scheme that the tutors will use.

column1: According to the lecturer's experience, how does student marking in peer reviews typically compare to tutor marking?
column2: Students tend to mark more generously than tutors.

column1: What is the pass mark for this degree course?
column2: The pass mark is 40 percent.

column1: What grade range is considered a good T1 grade that most students should aim for by answering questions as expected?
column2: The 60 to 70 percent range.

column1: What is required to achieve grades over 70 percent, corresponding to a first-class degree?
column2: You are required to go beyond what is taught in class, for example by doing some independent research.

column1: What are the two main assessments in this course and what is their weighting?
column2: A coursework (weekly tests) worth 50 percent and a final exam worth 50 percent.

column1: Why is it claimed that 'nobody understands how a computer works'?
column2: Because the complexity from the highest level (like a web page) down to the quantum physics level is too vast for any single person to comprehend.

column1: Computer speed is measured in gigahertz, which represents about a _____ mathematical operations per second.
column2: billion

column1: What key computer science concept is introduced as the solution to managing the immense complexity of computers?
column2: Abstraction.

column1: In the art analogy, which painter's style represents the ideal form of abstraction for computer science?
column2: Amedeo Modigliani, who simplifies a subject to its key features.

column1: Why are simplified diagrams often used in engineering instead of realistic pictures?
column2: They draw attention to the important features of a mechanism without the confusing detail of a realistic picture.

column1: Term: Abstraction (in Computer Science)
column2: A simplified representation of a piece of technology which emphasises the key details without distracting us with all the complexity.

column1: A single video can be represented physically by electrical charges, magnetisation, light pulses, or electromagnetic waves; thinking of it just as 'a video' is an example of what?
column2: An abstraction.

column1: What is the most basic abstraction used on a computer, where almost any data can be thought of in this way?
column2: Representing things as numbers.

column1: What do we call the tiny little squares that make up a computer picture?
column2: Pixels (short for picture elements).

column1: What are the three primary colours for light used in computer screens?
column2: Red, green, and blue.

column1: How is a single colour typically represented in a computer, based on the primary colours of light?
column2: By three numbers indicating the amount of red, green, and blue.

column1: In the layers of abstraction for a video, a grid of pixels forms a picture, and a sequence of pictures forms a _____.
column2: video

column1: What do we call a set of abstractions where each one is simpler and more abstract than the one below it?
column2: Layers of abstraction.

column1: What type of abstraction is needed to think about what a computer *does*, rather than just what it *represents*?
column2: An abstraction of the actions of a computer, called a notional machine.

column1: Term: Notional Machine
column2: A simplified, abstract model of how a piece of software or a computer works, focusing on its actions.

column1: In the notional machine of a video player, what term describes the indicator for the current position in the video?
column2: The playhead.

column1: The timeline and playhead together form a _____ _____ of a video player.
column2: notional machine

column1: What is the most important microchip in a computer that does all the calculations?
column2: The Central Processing Unit, or CPU.

column1: What is the function of the Random Access Memory (RAM)?
column2: It is where the computer stores all the data that it is currently working on.

column1: The fundamental operation of a computer can be described as an interaction between which two components?
column2: The CPU and memory (RAM).

column1: Describe the basic data flow when editing a sentence in a word processor.
column2: The sentence is loaded from memory into the CPU, edited, and then written back to memory.

column1: When you first open a document, where is it transferred from and to?
column2: It is transferred from the hard disk to RAM.

column1: When you type on a keyboard, the characters are sent to the CPU, which combines them with data from _____ and writes the result back to _____.
column2: RAM, RAM

column1: What action causes data from a document in RAM to be written to the hard disk?
column2: Saving the document.

column1: What feature allows data to be copied from memory to a device like a sound card without involving the CPU?
column2: Direct Memory Access (DMA).

column1: What is the main benefit of using Direct Memory Access (DMA)?
column2: It frees up the CPU to perform other tasks.

column1: What is the primary reason notional machines are useful for understanding complex systems?
column2: They are useful precisely because they are simple and easy to understand.

column1: The quizzes in the course are divided into two types, what are they?
column2: Practice quizzes to help you learn and quizzes that count towards your final mark.

column1: What must a student do to be well prepared for the coursework and final exam?
column2: Do all the exercises every week, including quizzes, peer reviews, and discussions.

column1: The core of a computer, which runs the instructions that make up computer programs, is the _____.
column2: CPU (Central Processing Unit)

column1: Why is it stated that just passively watching videos and reading the textbook is not enough to learn effectively?
column2: Because the science of the brain shows we don't learn well passively and need to practise what we learn.

column1: In the abstraction of a digital picture, a pixel is a tiny square that has a _____.
column2: colour

column1: When discussing layers of abstraction for a video, which abstraction is built directly upon the representation of data as numbers?
column2: The abstraction of pixels and colours.

column1: For which task would a computer scientist most likely need to think about a video at the pixel level of abstraction?
column2: Designing special effects or image filters.

column1: For which task would a computer scientist need to think about a video at the number and light pulse level of abstraction?
column2: Designing network protocols to transmit images and video.

column1: What is the notional machine of a video player built upon?
column2: The abstraction of a video as a sequence of pictures laid out on a timeline.

column1: According to the notional machine of a video player, what does hitting 'Play' do?
column2: It automatically moves the playhead forward along the timeline after every image or frame.
